questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes presents with fatigue, reduced urine output, and lower extremity edema. Laboratory tests show elevated serum creatinine and 4+ proteinuria. A renal biopsy is conducted to determine the cause. What is the most common histopathological finding in diabetic nephropathy as shown below?
questions.explanation:
Histopathological findings of diabetic nephropathy

Diffuse glomerulosclerosis

(Option D)
  • Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and expansion of the mesangium (due to accumulation of extracellular matrix) are the initial findings of diabetic nephropathy, which leads to diffuse glomerulosclerosis.
  • Seen in advanced diabetes and is a more common finding.

Nodular Glomerulosclerosis
(Option C)
  • It is due to the formation of eosinophilic PAS+ nodules in the glomerulus.
  • It is also called Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules, a characteristic finding of diabetic nephropathy, which is evident in the later stages of the disease.

Armani-Ebstein change (Option A)

It is characterised by the presence of lipid-laden tubular epithelial cells in the renal tubules.

Damage to Distal Convoluted Tubule (DCT)
  • Due to type 4 renal tubular acidosis.
  • Impaired excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions occurs due to resistance to aldosterone action at the epithelial sodium channels in the renal tubules, leading to hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with a 3-day history of decreased urine output, nausea, and generalized weakness. He was recently started on angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors for blood pressure control. On examination, his blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, heart rate is 96 bpm, and he appears dehydrated with dry mucous membranes. His urine output has decreased to 200 mL over the past 24 hours. Serum creatinine: 2.2 mg/dL (baseline 1.0 mg/dL) Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 28 mg/dL (baseline 14 mg/dL) Urine sodium: 10 mEq/L Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa): 1.2% Urine osmolality: 500 mOsm/kg Based on this patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which phase of acute kidney injury (AKI) is he most likely experiencing?

Match the following urine sodium concentration values to the likely correct cause of acute kidney injury (AKI): Urine Sodium Concentration (mEq/L) Type of AKI 1. < 20 mEq/L a. Renal AKI 2. > 40 mEq/L b. Pre-renal AKI 3. 20 - 40 mEq/L c. Post-renal AKI
questions.explanation:
Feature

Pre-Renal AKI

Renal (Intrinsic) AKI

Post-Renal AKI

Cause

Impaired renal perfusion

Direct kidney damage (e.g., ATN, glomerulonephritis)

Obstruction of urinary tract

Pathophysiology

Decreased blood flow to kidneys

Damage to kidney structures (e.g., tubules, glomeruli)

Urine backflow due to obstruction

Urine Sodium

< 20 mEq/L (conserving sodium)

> 40 mEq/L (impaired sodium reabsorption)

Variable, often normal(20-40 mEq/L) or slightly low

FENa

< 1% (kidneys conserve sodium)

> 2% (impaired tubular reabsorption)

Usually normal

Urine Osmolality

> 500 mOsm/kg (concentrated urine)

< 350 mOsm/kg (dilute urine)

Variable

BUN/ Creatinine Ratio

> 20:1 (indicates dehydration or low perfusion)

10-20:1 (or normal)

Normal or mildly elevated

Treatment
  • Fluid replacement (IV fluids for hypovolemia)
  • Address the underlying cause(e.g., volume resuscitation for dehydration, inotropes for heart failure, stopping nephrotoxic drugs).
  • Address the underlying cause(e.g., discontinuing nephrotoxic drugs, treating infection or glomerulonephritis).
  • Supportive care(e.g., dialysis in severe cases, fluid management, electrolyte correction).
  • Relieve the obstruction: Catheterization for bladder outlet obstruction, surgery or lithotripsy for urinary stones, or stent placement for ureteral obstructions.
  • Address any infection- Antibiotics (e.g., urinary tract infection, pyelonephritis).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with hypertension presents with severe left flank pain, nausea, and hematuria, his third episode in a year. A CT scan shows a 2.8 cm stone in the left ureter and several smaller stones in the left kidney. What is the preferred surgical method and prevention strategy? PCNL: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy ESWL: Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy
questions.explanation:
Medical management

Surgical Management
  • Analgesics like diclofenac, ketorolac, tramadol
  • Fluid therapy: IVF (intravenous fluids) are administered to prevent dehydration
  • Alpha 1 blocker: Tamsulosin (relaxes ureter and expels the stone).
  • Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL): Indicated if the size of the calculi <2 cm. (Contraindicated in pregnancy and bleeding diathesis). (Option C, D)
  • PCNL (Percutaneous nephrolithotomy): If the size is >2 cm. (Option B)
  • Uretrorenoscopy
  • Retrograde intrarenal surgery
  • Pyelolithotomy and nephrolithotomy (rarely used).

Type of stone

Preventive measures

Calcium oxalate stones
  • Maintain normal calcium intake (1200mg/dL)
  • Low sodium intake
  • Low animal protein intake
  • Thiazide (Chlorthalidone)
  • DASH (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) diet

Calcium phosphate stones
  • Low sodium diet
  • Thiazide (chlorthalidone)
  • Alkali supplementation (potassium citrate or bicarbonate)

Uric acid stones
  • Alkalisation of urine and maintaining urine pH 6.5 (by increasing fruits and vegetables in the diet, cutting off animal protein, and, if needed, alkali supplements)
  • Xanthine oxidase inhibitor (Allopurinol or Febuxostat) to prevent uricosuria

Cystine stones
  • Tiopronin (preferred) or penicillamine
  • Alkalisation of urine to pH 7.5 (potassium citrate or bicarbonate)

Struvite stones
  • Treat the infection (antibiotics)
  • Acetohydroxamic acid

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe, sharp pain in his left flank radiating to his groin. He reports nausea and has vomited once. Lab investigations show gross hematuria. What is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis in this condition? (DTPA: Diethylenetriamine Pentaacetic Acid)
Match the following renal stones with their microscopic appearance, 1. Calcium oxalate dihydrate a. 2. Calcium phosphate b. 3. Struvite stone c. 4. Cystine stone d.
questions.explanation:
Calcium oxalate

  • Most common type of renal stone.
  • Types: Monohydrate and dihydrate forms
  • Causes: Hypercalciuria (most common), hypercalcaemia, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria, hypocitraturia.
  • Microscopic appearance:
    • Monohydrate crystals: Dumbbell or picket fence appearance
    • Dihydrate crystals: Envelope shaped

 

Calcium phosphate

  • Causes: Renal tubular acidosis Type I, primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Microscopic appearance: Rosette-shaped crystals
  

Uric acid stone

  • These crystals are soft, break easily, and can adopt any shape.
  • Caused by conditions resulting in hyperuricosuria (gout).
  

Cystine stone

  • They are the hardest stones.
  • Causes: Cystinuria, cystinosis (inborn metabolic error, causes death in 1st year of life)
  • Microscopic appearance: Hexagonal shape
 

Struvite stones or Staghorn calculi

  • Also known as triple phosphate stone (MgNH4Po4)
  • Caused by recurrent UTI (urinary tract infection)
  • Causative organism: Proteus mirabilis.
  • Microscopic appearance: Coffin-lid appearance of crystals.
  

Ciprofloxacin stones

  • Stellate shaped
  

Amoxicillin stones

  • Broom shaped

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents at the clinic with sharp, intermittent pain in her lower back and abdomen, along with nausea, vomiting, and hematuria. She has experienced similar episodes thrice in the past two years despite adhering to dietary and lifestyle recommendations. What is the most likely cause of her recurrent symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Risk factors

Description

Dietary factors
  • Low calcium intake can lead to stone formation (low calcium can lead to high oxalate absorption).
  • High oxalate intake
  • High animal protein intake (leads to hypercalciuria and hyperuricosuria)
  • Higher sodium and sucrose intake (hypercalciuria)
  • Dehydration or inadequate fluid intake (leads to volume depletion)
  • Sugar-sweetened beverages

Non-dietary factors
  • More common in middle age group
  • Low urine output (due to a hot environment, lack of access to water or a bathroom)

Urinary factors
  • Hypercalciuria
  • Hyperuricosuria
  • High oxalate excretion in urine
  • Low urine excretion of citrate (citrate inhibits stone formation)
  • Urinary pH:
    • Acidic: Uric acid stone formation
    • Alkaline: Calcium phosphate stone formation

Associated disorders
  • Idiopathic hypercalciuria (recurrent renal stones) (Option A)
  • Inflammatory Bowel disease (IBD), especially Crohn’s Disease (calcium oxalate stones)
  • Gastric bypass surgery
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism (calcium oxalate stones) (Option B)
  • Obesity
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Diabetes mellitus (Type 2) (Option C)
  • Renal tubular acidosis Type 1 or distal (calcium phosphate stones)
  • Disorders like hypertension, gout (Option D), cardiovascular disease, cholelithiasis, reduced bone mineral density, and chronic kidney disease can also increase the risk for stone formation.

Genetic disorders
  • Family history of stones
  • Medullary sponge kidney: A congenital disorder marked by malformations of the papillary collecting ducts in the renal pyramids, leading to microscopic and large medullary cysts, often presenting as renal stones.
  • Cystinuria: Reabsorption of filtered cystine, ornithine, arginine, and lysine caused by mutations in the SLC3A1 amino acid transporter gene, resulting in a high cystine concentration in urine and the formation of cystine stones.
  • Primary hyperoxaluria: It is characterised by excessive endogenous oxalate production by the liver.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden, sharp right flank pain radiating to her groin, along with nausea, vomiting, and hematuria. The physician orders an urgent ultrasound to rule out which of the following emergency conditions?

A 62-year-old male with a 15-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes presents for follow-up, reporting fatigue and mild lower extremity oedema. Examination reveals blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg and abdominal mass. Radiological investigation indicates bilateral kidney enlargement. Which of the following is not a cause of bilateral kidney enlargement?
questions.explanation:
Causes of Renal Enlargement

Bilateral

Unilateral

Can be either
  • Diabetic nephropathy (most common)
  • HIV nephropathy (FSGS)
  • Amyloidosis
  • Polycystic kidney disease
  • Leukaemia
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Acromegaly
  • Renal vein thrombosis
  • Renal artery infarction
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Acute pyelonephritis
  • Renal lymphoma

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes presents for a routine follow-up. Her serum creatinine and potassium levels are normal, but she has microalbuminuria and an HbA1c of 8%. Her blood pressure and pulse are within normal limits, and she is currently on metformin for diabetes management. What should be the next step in her management?

options.label: C
options.text: Stop Metformin and start a different OHA

questions.explanation:
Management of Diabetic nephropathy

Oral Hypoglycemic agents (OHAs)
  • SGLT2 inhibitors lower the risk of cardiovascular events and renal failure; they are also recently approved for HFpEF.
  • For HbA1C < 9.5%, OHAs can be used
  • Metformin is withheld if eGFR is < 30 mL/min/1.73 m2 (Option C), and drugs safe in renal failure can be used like
    • Glipizide
    • Linagliptin
    • Repaglinide

Insulin

80% of the calculated dose is started if HbA1C > 9.5% (Option B)

Antihypertensives
  • In the presence of microalbuminuria, ACEi and ARBs have shown evidence to slow the progression of nephropathy if started in early stages.
  • In hypertension, for BP > 130/90, ACEi or ARBs are preferred
  • If BP is still not under control, Calcium channel blocker (CCB) can be added
  • Thiazide diuretic - in the presence of oedema (Option A)
  • If eGFR <30 ml/min, then the diuretic used - Metolazone.
  • ACEi/ARB comes with a side effect of hyperkalemia; hence, regular monitoring of potassium is necessary.
  • In the presence of hyperkalemia, ACEi/ARB is replaced by CCB
  • Alpha blocker (Prazosin) - hyperkalemia in ESRD.

For Hyperkalemia

K Binding resins (Bind to potassium in the gastrointestinal tract and promote its excretion)

  • Sodium polystyrene sulfonate
  • Patiromer
  • Sodium zirconate

Renal Transplant

If eGFR is < 20 mL/min/1.73m2.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents for a routine check-up. His blood pressure is under control, but laboratory tests reveal microalbuminuria. What stage of diabetic nephropathy does this patient likely represent?
questions.explanation:
Stages of Diabetic nephropathy

Stage 1
  • Is the stage of glomerular hyperfiltration due to nephron hypertrophy and hyperplasia, leading to microalbuminuria (30 - 330 mg/day)
  • It is a reversible condition of management.

Stage 2
  • It takes more than 10 years to progress from stage 1
  • Microalbuminuria is seen in almost all the patients in this stage
  • BP is usually normal; 24-hour ambulatory BP can show absent nocturnal dipping and wide pulse pressure.
  • Renal biopsy reveals Glomerular basement membrane (GBM) thickening + mesangial matrix expansion

Stage 3
  • Occasionally, oedema is present.
  • Proteinuria +
  • Blood pressure: Incipient increase and exercise-induced HTN.
  • Renal biopsy reveals arteriolar hyalinosis, diffuse glomerulosclerosis and nodular glomerulosclerosis

Stage 4
  • Elevated Se.creatinine
  • Proteinuria (nephrotic range).
  • Sustained HTN
  • Renal biopsy reveals fibrosis.

Stage 5
  • End stage renal disease
  • Progression is after 25 - 30 years of diabetes
  • eGFR drops < 15 ml/min

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with hypertension and Type 2 diabetes presents with fatigue, mild shortness of breath, decreased urine output, increased lethargy, and mild ankle swelling. His vital signs show BP 140/85 mmHg and HR 88 bpm. He has been diagnosed with Stage 1 acute kidney injury (AKI). What is the expected elevation in serum creatinine levels for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Staging of the severity of AKI

Stages

Serum creatinine

Urine output

Stage 1

1.5–1.9 times baseline (Option C)

(OR)

≥0.3 mg/dL (≥26.5 μmol/L) increased

<0.5 mL/kg/hr for 6–12 hours

Stage 2

2.0–2.9 times baseline (Option B)

<0.5 mL/kg/hr for ≥12 hours

Stage 3

≥3.0 times baseline (Option A)

(OR)

Serum creatinine increase by ≥4.0 mg/dL (≥353.6 μmol/L)

(OR)

Initiation of renal replacement therapy

(OR)

In patients <18 years of age, there is a decrease in eGFR to <35 mL/min per 1.73 metre square.

<0.3 mL/kg/hr for ≥24 hours

(OR)

Anuria for ≥12 hours

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with long-standing type 2 diabetes presents with worsening oedema. Laboratory tests show elevated serum creatinine and significant proteinuria. Which of the following mechanisms primarily contributes to the proteinuria in her condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. Glycation leading to mesangial expansion
questions.explanation:
Diabetic Nephropathy

Pathogenesis

Risk Factors
  • Uncontrolled DM
  • Hypertension
  • Dyslipidemia
  • Smoking
  • Family history of diabetic nephropathy
  • Genetic predispositions
  • Other microvascular complications

Progression
  • > 5 years in type 1 diabetes
  • Gradual (> 10 - 20 years) in type 2 diabetes.

Screening
  • By regularly monitoring AER and serum creatinine.
  • Albumin of 30-300 mg/gm is moderate albuminuria.
  • False positive albuminuria can be seen in
    • Hypertension
    • Congestive heart failure
    • Pyelonephritis
  • Serum creatinine is not an early finding, as it only increases after increased kidney damage.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a 5-year history of diabetes and recently diagnosed hypertension, who began taking telmisartan one month ago, returns for a follow-up. Investigations reveal hyperkalemia (6.2 mEq/L), serum creatinine of 1.3 mg/dL (baseline 0.9 mg/dL), and metabolic acidosis (pH = 7.1) following a recent upper respiratory infection. What management steps should be considered for her condition? Stop Telmisartan Insulin infusion with dextrose Start Calcium acetate Start Sodium bicarbonate Start ACEi temporarily
questions.explanation:
Management of AKI

Fluid Management
  • Strict I/O charting
  • IV hydration (avoid Hypervolemia)
  • Input ﬂuids should be calculated as Urinary output + Insensible loss (loss from skin and breathing- 800 ml/day)
  • IV is decided based on electrolytes
    • Hypochloremia - Normal saline
    • Normal chloride values - Ringer lactate
    • Rhabdomyolysis - Sodium bicarbonate + Normal saline (Forced alkaline diuresis)
  • Hypervolemia: 200 mg bolus Furosemide followed by 10 to 40 mg/hr in a drip +/- Thiazide diuretic
  • Fluid restriction and increased salt intake in case of Hyponatremia

Metabolic Acidosis
  • Sodium Bicarbonate - 0.5×weight×(24−actual value): Half dose stat and Half in divided doses over 24 hours.
  • Overcorrection may lead to metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and volume overload.

Hyperkalemia
  • Reduce dietary potassium intake.
  • ACEi or ARBs are stopped as they contribute to hyperkalemia
  • In case of moderate (6.1 to 7.0 mEq/L) to severe hyperkalemia (>7 mEq/L)
    • IV Calcium gluconate
    • IV insulin infusion with dextrose
    • Salbutamol nebulization

Hyperphosphatemia
  • Reduce the dietary phosphate intake.
  • Phosphate binders are used like
    • Calcium acetate
    • Sevelamer
    • Aluminium hydroxide with meals

Severe HTN
  • IV Labetalol and ACEi (in Scleroderma)

Dialysis

Indications

  • Metabolic Acidosis (pH < 7.1 after correction)
  • Hyperkalemia (Not responding to correction)
  • eGFR < 10 ml/min
  • Volume Overload (Not responding to Rx)
  • Uremic pericarditis (Absolute indication)
  • Uremic encephalopathy

Disequilibrium after aggressive hemodialysis can be managed by Mannitol, as it can lead to cerebral edema if untreated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with known lupus presents with worsening renal function over the past week. She reports increased fatigue and joint pain. Laboratory results Serum creatinine: 4.2 mg/dL (baseline 0.9 mg/dL) Urinalysis: 4+ protein, 2+ blood Urine protein-to-creatinine ratio (UPCR): 4 g/g (baseline 0.15 g/g) What is the most appropriate test to further evaluate her condition?
questions.explanation:
Workup for Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)

Urine findings

Urine microscopy
  • “Muddy brown” granular casts: Acute tubular necrosis
  • Dysmorphic RBC or RBC casts: Acute glomerulonephritis
  • Eosinophiluria in interstitial nephritis, pyelonephritis, cystitis, atheroembolic disease, or glomerulonephritis.
  • Oxalate crystals: Ethylene glycol toxicity

Urine osmolarity


 

FeNa: Fractional excretion of sodium is calculated.

In Diarrhea

In Ischemic AKI
  • FeNa < 1%
  • Less urinary sodium
  • Urine osmolarity - 500 mOsm/Kg
  • FeNa > 1%
  • High urinary sodium
  • Urine osmolarity - 300 mOsm/Kg

Blood Investigations

KFT

(Option B)
  • Elevated Se.Cr, BUN
  • Hyponatremia (Hypervolemic hyponatremia): Due to the increase in body water and body surface.
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypochloremia (Seen in vomiting)
  • Hyperphosphatemia, Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperuricemia (as in Tumor lysis syndrome)

ABG

  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Increased anion gap: Ethylene glycol poisoning
  • Low anion gap: Multiple myeloma

Blood Culture

To rule out Sepsis

Coagulogram

Assess bleeding risk and complications.

CPK MM level

Elevated in Rhabdomyolysis

Autoimmune panel

To identify Autoimmune causes of AKI

Anti-phospholipase A2 receptor antibodies

Found in membranous nephropathy.

ADAMTS 13 Level (Option C)

Helps in managing AKI in the context of TTP

Radiological evaluation

Ultrasound

To evaluate Post-renal causes of AKI

CT abdomen (Option A)

In suspected Renal obstruction.

Renal Biopsy

When other conditions are ruled out, renal biopsy helps in the diagnosis of

  • Glomerulonephritis,
  • Vasculitis,
  • Interstitial nephritis,
  • Myeloma kidney,
  • Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) and Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)
  • Allograft dysfunction

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with newly diagnosed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma presents two days after starting chemotherapy with nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and mild confusion. Lab results reveal elevated potassium, phosphate, uric acid, and low calcium. What is true regarding the prevention of this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Calcium supplementation is the primary intervention

questions.explanation:
Prevention approach of Tumor Lysis syndrome

Low-risk Patients

Regular monitoring of serum electrolytes

Intermediate and High-risk patients-

High baseline uric acid, High LDH, High WBC count, Large tumor size- >10 cm
  • Maintain hydration with IV half normal saline or normal saline at 3000 mL/m²/day.
  • Administer allopurinol at 300 mg/m²/day.
  • Monitor potassium, phosphate, calcium, uric acid, LDH, and serum creatinine every 8–12 hours (Option B).
 

*Rasburicase is contraindicated in patients with G6PD deficiency.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a 10-year history of cirrhosis secondary to alcohol use presents to the emergency department with worsening fatigue, abdominal distension, and confusion over the past two weeks. The patient also mentions reduced urine output for the past 48 hrs. His lab tests reveal a serum creatinine of 2.3 mg/dL, and his urine analysis shows a low sodium concentration. What is the appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Hepatorenal syndrome

Pathophysiology

Renal vasoconstriction occurs due to altered systemic vascular resistance in advanced liver disease, leading to functional kidney impairment.

Types

Type 1

Type 2

Progression

Rapid (within 1 - 2 weeks)

Gradual

Clinical parameters

￪Serum creatinine

￬ eGFR and ￪ Serum creatinine, but kidney function is stable comparatively.

Progress

Poor

Comparatively better

Diagnostic factors
  • Presence of large ascites
  • Elevated serum creatinine
  • Low urine sodium concentration
  • Absence of other identifiable causes of renal failure.

Management
  • Withhold diuretics as they can worsen renal perfusion.
  • Albumin infusion: 1 g/kg/day to improve intravascular volume and renal perfusion.
  • Vasoconstrictors: Terlipressin or a combination of midodrine, octreotide, and albumin infusion.
  • Definitive treatment: Liver transplantation. (Option A)

questions.text: A 70-year-old female with diabetes, hypertension, and CKD presents to the emergency department with chest pain and dyspnea. An ECG indicates possible myocardial infarction. The cardiologist recommends a Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) coronary angiography. Which test should be performed before the CT scan?
questions.explanation:
Contrast-induced nephropathy

Clinical progression
  • Onset: Elevated serum creatinine can be observed 1 to 2 days after contrast administration.
  • Peak Elevation: Typically reached within 3 to 5 days.
  • Resolution: Usually begins within 1 week.

High-risk groups
  • Individuals with pre-existing renal disease
  • Patients with multiple myeloma
  • Diabetic patients, especially those with renal impairment
  • Elderly patients and those with other comorbid conditions

Prevention
  • Hydration: Ensure adequate hydration before and after contrast administration.
  • Kidney function evaluation: Perform serum creatinine tests prior to the procedure.

Treatment
  • Intravenous hydration (IV fluids to maintain renal perfusion)
  • N-acetylcysteine (May offer protective effects on the kidneys)
  • IV Sodium bicarbonate (Urine alkalinisation and renal protection)

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents after being trapped under debris for 4 hours, reporting severe leg pain, fatigue, and decreased urine output. Examination shows anxiety, pain, and swelling with bruising in both legs. Serum creatinine is 3.0 mg/dL (baseline 0.9 mg/dL), and BUN is 60 mg/dL. All of the following are associated with exogenous nephrotoxins except,
questions.explanation:
Exogenous Nephrotoxins

Contrast agents
  • Iodinated contrast agents (CT)
  • Gadolinium (MRI)
  • Sodium phosphate solutions (bowel purgatives)
  • Contrast-induced nephropathy (Option C)
    • An increase in creatinine levels occurs within 1 to 2 days post-procedure, with peak levels reached by 3 to 5 days and typically resolves within a week.
    • Treatment consists of IV fluids, sodium bicarbonate, and N-acetylcysteine.

Drugs
  • Vancomycin (Tubular injury)
  • Amphotericin B (Hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia)
  • Aminoglycosides (Non-oliguric kidney, i.e., urine output >400 mL/day)
  • Acyclovir (Tubular obstruction)
  • Some other drugs, like penicillins, cephalosporins, quinolones, sulfonamides, and rifampin, can also cause AKI.

Chemotherapeutic agents (Option A)
  • Cisplatin (mostly used in lung cancer)
  • Carboplatin

Toxic ingestions
  • Ethylene glycol (Option B)
    • An antifreeze agent found in automobiles can precipitate calcium oxalate crystals in the kidney tubules, leading to injury or obstruction and reduced urine output.
    • The antidote is fomepizole.
  • Diethylene glycol, often found as an adulterant in pharmaceutical products like cough syrups, can lead to metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, and anuria.
  • Aristolochic acid is derived from contaminated medicinal herbs and agricultural practices, resulting in "Chinese herb nephropathy" and "Balkan nephropathy."
  • Melamine has been linked to contaminated foodstuffs, leading to nephrolithiasis and acute kidney injury (AKI).

Endogenous Nephrotoxins
  • Compounds: Myoglobin (blocks tubule), hemoglobin, uric acid, and myeloma light chains.
  • Associated conditions:
    • Rhabdomyolysis: Due to crush injury, prolonged immobilization, prolonged seizures, heatstroke, malignant hyperthermia, inhalational anesthetic (Halothane), and drugs like succinylcholine.
    • Mismatched blood transfusion (Option D): Type 2 hypersensitivity.
  • Tumour lysis syndrome occurs in high-grade lymphomas like Burkitt lymphoma, ALL (acute lymphoblastic leukemia), and AML (acute myeloid leukemia).

questions.text: A 50-year-old breast cancer patient undergoing cisplatin chemotherapy presents with increased fatigue, nausea, decreased appetite, and reduced urine output, along with mild leg swelling. Her serum creatinine is 2.0 mg/dL (baseline 0.8 mg/dL), and BUN is 40 mg/dL. Which of the following novel markers is preferred in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Novel Biomarkers

Description

KIM-1 (Kidney injury molecule-1)

(Option A)

A type 1 transmembrane protein found in proximal tubular cells can be detected in urine and plasma following ischemic, nephrotoxic or chemotherapy-induced kidney injury (It is highly specific for cisplatin-induced tubular necrosis).

It can be measured in both blood and urine.

NGAL (Neutrophil Gelatinase Associated Lipocalin) or Lipocalin-2 or Siderocalin

(Option B)

  • NGAL is a protein found in human neutrophil granules that binds iron siderophore complexes and provides tissue-protective effects in the proximal tubule.
  • It can be detected in plasma and urine following inflammation and kidney injury.
  • It is a good and sensitive marker but is less specific for tubular damage.
  • It is very specific for cardio-pulmonary bypass-associated AKI

SUPAR (Soluble Urokinase Plasminogen Activator Receptor)

(Option C)

A glycoprotein detected only in plasma and helps assess kidney health and injury.`

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with chronic heart failure (CHF) and hypertension presents with 2 days of worsening fatigue, decreased urine output, and mild confusion. He appears dehydrated with ankle oedema. His BP is 85/55 mmHg, HR is 102 bpm, and serum creatinine is 2.4 mg/dL (baseline 1.0 mg/dL). Which of the following antihypertensives is considered safe in this condition?

A 45-year-old female presents with 3 days of severe watery diarrhea, fatigue, and lightheadedness. Her BP is 90/60 mmHg, HR is 110 bpm, serum creatinine is 1.8 mg/dL (baseline 0.9 mg/dL), and BUN is 30 mg/dL. Immediate fluid resuscitation was initiated. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause pre-renal azotemia?
questions.explanation:
Glomerular causes

Tubular and interstitial causes

Vascular causes
  • Acute glomerulonephritis (Option A)
  • Sepsis or infection
  • Ischaemia
  • Nephrotoxins
  • HUS (hemolytic-uremic syndrome)
  • TTP (thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura)
  • Malignant hypertension (Option B)
  • Vasculitis
  • Athero-embolization kidney disease
  • Renal vein thrombosis
  • Renal artery embolus
